content:
EXISTING STRUCTURES
────────────────────────
### Resource Depot & Smelting Facility at base position (x=-4.5, y=18.5)
Consists of:
• Wooden Chest at (x=-4.5, y=18.5) serving as central storage.
• Stone Furnace at (x=-3.0, y=19.0) for iron smelting.
• Stone Furnace at (x=-4.0, y=21.0) for copper plate production.
• Burner Inserter at (x=0.5, y=21.5) with drop position at (x=0.5, y=20.5).

### Automation Lab & Steam Power System (Integrated System) at base configuration
Consists of:
• Lab at (x=-7.5, y=18.5) dedicated to automation research.
• Boiler at (x=-5.5, y=24.0) supplying thermal energy.
• Steam Engine (Generator) at (x=-0.5, y=24.5) delivering power output.
• Offshore Pump at (x=-7.5, y=25.5) supporting fluid intake.
• Electricity Group with small electric poles at (x=-0.5, y=11.5), (x=-7.5, y=15.5), (x=-4.5, y=15.5), (x=3.5, y=19.5) and (x=1.5, y=22.5).
• Two PipeGroups forming the fluid network at (x=-10.5, y=16.5) & (x=-12.5, y=18.5) and at (x=-8.5, y=20.5) & (x=-2.5, y=21.5).
 
### Copper Cable Factory at position (x=1.5, y=19.5)
Consists of:
• Assembling Machine at (x=1.5, y=19.5) running the copper-cable recipe.
• Burner Inserter at (x=1.5, y=17.5).
• Input Chest at (x=2.5, y=17.5) for copper plates.
• Output Chest at (x=1.5, y=21.5) for copper-cable dispatch.
• Dedicated Copper Buffer Chest at (x=-5.5, y=21.5).
• Dedicated Transport Belt Segment at (x=0.5, y=17.5) connecting outputs.
• Additional Burner Inserters at (x=2.5, y=16.5) and (x=3.5, y=17.5).

### Copper Extraction System (adjacent to the copper smelting furnace)
Consists of:
• Extraction Burner Inserter at (x=-3.5, y=23.5) with pickup at (x=-3.5, y=22.5) and drop at (x=-3.5, y=24.5).
• Copper Buffer Chest at (x=-3.5, y=26.5).
• Chest Extraction Burner Inserter at (x=-3.5, y=27.5) with pickup at (x=-3.5, y=26.5) and drop at (x=-3.5, y=28.5).
• Belt Source Inserter with extraction drop at (x=-3.5, y=25.5).

### Extraction Belt Depot at position (x=3.5, y=15.5)
Consists of:
• Wooden Chest at (x=3.5, y=15.5) serving as the belt depot.
• Dedicated Transport Belt Segment at (x=4.5, y=15.5) for copper plate conveyance.
• Depot Burner Inserter at (x=3.5, y=14.5) with pickup at (x=3.5, y=15.5) and drop at (x=3.5, y=13.5).

### Belt Connection Target Setup for Copper Extraction
Consists of:
• Extraction Source: Wooden Chest at (x=3.5, y=15.5).
• Extraction Inserter at (x=4.5, y=15.5) with pickup at (x=3.5, y=15.5) and drop at (x=5.5, y=15.5).
• Manual Transport Belt Chain connecting production outputs:
 – Horizontal segments at (x=7.5, y=15.5) and (x=8.5, y=15.5) (placement at (x=6.5, y=15.5) was not possible due to an existing entity).
 – Vertical segments along x=8.5 at (y=14.5), (y=13.5), (y=12.5) and (y=11.5) (placement at (x=8.5, y=10.5) encountered an occupancy error).
• New Target Inserter at (x=8.5, y=9.5) with pickup at (x=8.5, y=10.5) and drop at (x=8.5, y=8.5).
• Belt Chain Burner Inserter Refueling Subsystem deploying:
 – Burner Inserters at (x=6.5, y=9.5), (x=7.5, y=9.5), (x=8.5, y=9.5) and (x=5.5, y=11.5) that have been successfully refueled.
 – Burner Inserters at (x=3.5, y=14.5) and (x=5.5, y=14.5) which continue to exhibit fuel warnings.
 
Recent system integration cycles have further consolidated electrical and logistic networks across all these structures, ensuring that all entity clusters are now fully included in the master global blueprint.

ERROR TIPS
────────────────────────
• Fuel Management and Resource Supply Issues
 – Ensure uninterrupted fuel delivery to burner-operated modules. Persistent NO_FUEL warnings (e.g. in the boiler and select burner inserters) require proactive refueling to maintain continuous operation.
 
• Power Connection and Electrical Stability
 – Verify that every power-dependent module is properly connected. Continuous NO_POWER and NOT_CONNECTED statuses (notably in the assembling machine and steam engine) indicate the need for a thorough reconnection check.
 
• Input Resource Provisioning
 – Coordinate and synchronize resource delivery to production units. Furnaces experiencing NO_INGREDIENTS errors suggest that input buffers are not being adequately replenished.
 
• Placement and Occupancy Verification
 – Check target tiles for occupancy before placing new transport belts or network segments. Historical placement failures due to existing entities necessitate pre-validation of placement areas.
 
• Timing and Synchronization Overheads
 – Introduce adequate wait intervals between auto reconfiguration and maintenance routines to allow systems to stabilize. This minimizes data discrepancies and misalignments in network connections.
 
• Persistent Core Module Connection Issues
 – Reassess critical facilities—including the smelting furnace at (x=-3.0, y=19.0), the assembling machine at (x=1.5, y=19.5), the boiler at (x=-5.5, y=24.0), and the steam engine at (x=-0.5, y=24.5)—to ensure they receive proper inputs, fuel, and power connections. Monitor auto-remediation cycles closely and intervene manually where corrective measures remain active.
